author: Jim Le <@jimle_uk>
description: TFL created a tube map commerating Black history month by renaming 272 to honour historical figures and events. This is a json mapping of the names and stations.
credits: List of names and mappings to stations was scraped from https://blackculturalarchives.org/bca-x-tfl-list. Station codes via https://content.tfl.gov.uk/station-abbreviations.pdf

data.name: AA O'Browne
data.description: First West African Jazz musician to release an album in Poland
data.image_attribution: Adrian Grycuk, CC BY-SA 3.0 PL <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/pl/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: AG Minns
data.description: Medical doctor and the first Black mayor in Britain

data.name: Ade Bashorun
data.description: Nigerian Percussionist

data.name: Africanus Horton
data.description: Writer and esteemed medical surgeon, at the time he was called the 'father of of African political thought'
data.image_attribution: Army Medical Department, England, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Albert May
data.description: Black Circus Performer
data.image_attribution: Not known - from the archives of Sunderland Museum and Winter Gardens, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Alfred Fagon
data.description: Playwright, poet, and actor

data.name: Althea McNish
data.description: Textile designer and first Caribbean woman to achieve international prominence in this field

data.name: Ambrose Campbell
data.description: Nigerian musician who formed Britain's first black band

data.name: Amryl Johnson
data.description: Writer whose works featured the diasporic nature of her life and the hostility she faced in Britain

data.name: Amy A Garvey
data.description: Pan-African Activist, founder of the Negro World newspaper and wife of Marcus Garvey
data.image_attribution: The Marcus Garvey and UNIA Papers Project

data.name: Amy Barbour-James
data.description: Civil rights activist and civil servant

data.name: Amy Height
data.description: Actor, comedian, and music hall entertainer
data.image_attribution: unknown but before 1913, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Andrea Levy
data.description: Author and social commentator. Her fourth novel, Small Island won critical acclaim and literary awards

data.name: Andrew Salkey
data.description: Novelist, poet, and journalist

data.name: Andy Hamilton
data.description: Jazz saxophonist and composer
data.image_attribution: Si Hammond Birmingham, UK, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Annie Brewster
data.description: Ophthalmic Nurse

data.name: Arthur Wharton
data.description: Widely considered to be the first Black professional football player in the world and the first to play in the English Football League

data.name: Asquith Xavier
data.description: British Railway worker who ended the recruitment colour bar at his workplace

data.name: Aubrey Williams
data.description: Artist

data.name: Avril Coleridge-Taylor
data.description: Pianist, conductor, and composer. First female conductor of HMS Royal Marines and daughter of acclaimed composer and conductor, Samuel Coleridge-Taylor

data.name: Ayuba Suleiman Diallo
data.description: Best known for his memoirs as an enslaved Muslim Nobleman
data.image_attribution: William Hoare, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: BLK Arts Group
data.description: Black arts collective formed in Wolverhampton

data.name: Barbara Burford
data.description: Medical researcher, civil servant, and writer, with an award in her name to recognise LGBT invididuals who have excelled in their field

data.name: Baron Baker
data.description: Campaigner for racial justice and known as the 'man who discovered Brixton' and with others established a black community in the area

data.name: Belle Davis
data.description: Choreographer, singer, and dancer
data.image_attribution: Published by Falk in the USA, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Ben Enwonwu
data.description: Painter and sculptor, celebrated as 'Africa's Greatest Artist'

data.name: Ben Simmons
data.description: On 25 September 1929, the Hull Daily Mail published an article entitled ‘Interesting Hull Wedding: H.M.V. Coloured Artist and Local Bride’ about the marriage of Ben Simmons and Margaret Wyng that took place at St Nicholas Church, Hessle Common. While the bride was a local woman born in Hull, their wedding was described as, “unique in that the bridegroom is a chief of the Gold Coast of West Africa.”

data.name: Bernie Grant Centre
data.description: Cultural centre named after politician, MP, and racial justice activist, Bernie Grant, who died in 2000

data.name: Berto Pasuka
data.description: Dancer and choreographer who founded the 1st black-led dance company in modern times

data.name: Betty Campbell
data.description: Activist and Wales' first Black headteacher

data.name: Betty Peters
data.description: Posed for sculptor Jacob Epstein who depicted his Black models as full human beings

data.name: Bill Richmond
data.description: Boxer in the Georgian era

data.name: Billy Waters
data.description: 19th-century busker who performed on the streets of London

data.name: Black Art An'done
data.description: First major exhibition by a group of Black artists in Wolverhampton. Crediting for spawning a new wave of Black art from the children of the Windrush generation

data.name: Black Cultural Archives
data.description: The only national heritage centre dedicated to collecting, preserving, and celebrating the histories of African and Caribbean people in Britain

data.name: Black Trans Alliance
data.description: Black Queer and trans-led organisation, supporting Black trans and non-binary people in London

data.name: Black-Art Gallery
data.description: A seminal gallery that brought diversity to the UK art world

data.name: BlackOut UK
data.description: Not-for-profit social enterprise, run and owned by a volunteer collective of Black gay men

data.name: Blair Blenman
data.description: Weightlifter and Olympian

data.name: Bob Travers
data.description: Lightweight boxer and one of the best of his time. He was also known as the 'Black Wonder'

data.name: Brenda Agard
data.description: Photographer, poet, and storyteller whose work centred on the resilience of the Black woman
data.image_attribution: Nicolet1327, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Briton Hammon
data.description: His autobiography published in 1760 and considered to be the first enslaved narrative for a Black American, recounts his imprisonment, daring escapes, and travel to the UK before returning to the US
data.image_attribution: Briton Hammon, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Buchi Emecheta
data.description: Novelist and author of more than 20 books

data.name: CLR James
data.description: Historian, journalist, and Marxist whose novel was the first to be published by a Black West Indian in 1936

data.name: Cab Kaye
data.description: Jazz singer and pianist who combined jazz techniques with his Ghanian heritage. His refusal to play when a patron was refused entry to one of his shows due to their race led to regular acceptance of Black people at public UK venues
data.image_attribution: Dixie Solleveld, CC BY 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Carlos Trower
data.description: Tight rope performer known as the Prince of the Air

data.name: Carmel Stuart
data.description: Jamaican Girlfriend of Muriel Belcher, an English nightclub owner who was the founder and proprietress of a private drinking club known as The Colony Room.

data.name: Carmen Beckford
data.description: Nurse, race equality campaigner, and instrumental in setting up St Paul's Carnival in Bristol

data.name: Carmen England
data.description: Successful businesswoman and one of the founders of Notting Hill Carnival
data.image_attribution: ChrisO at the English-language Wikipedia, CC BY-SA 3.0 <http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Cassie Walmer
data.description: Singer and dancer

data.name: Catalina of Motril
data.description: Enslaved Moorish royal servant of the house of Katherine of Aragon

data.name: Cec Thompson
data.description: Professional rugby league player who was active between the 1940s-1960s. In 1951, he became the second ever Black man to play for Great Britain

data.name: Cecil Belfield Clarke
data.description: Medical doctor and prominent gay Black leader in the League of Coloured Peoples

data.name: Cecile Nobrega
data.description: Teacher, poet, playwright, composer and community activist

data.name: Cesar Picton
data.description: Freed man who became a successful and wealthy coal merchant and business owner
data.image_attribution: Stevekeiretsu, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Charlie Williams
data.description: One of the first black football players who later became Britain's first well-known Black stand-up comedians

data.name: Chester Harriott
data.description: Pianist and entertainer and one half of variety act Harriot and Evans who performed for society figures and British royalty

data.name: Chinwe Chukwuogo-Roy
data.description: Visual artist and one of two Nigerian-born artists to paint official portraits Queen Elizabeth II

data.name: Christian F Cole
data.description: Sierra Leonese lawyer and the first African barrister to practice in English courts

data.name: Clare Deniz
data.description: Jazz pianist who played with many jazz and swing bands in London's evolving jazz scene from WWII until the 1980s

data.name: Claude McKay
data.description: Writer and poet

data.name: Claudia Jones
data.description: Journalist and Communist political activist. Founder of Britain's first major black newspaper, the West Indian Gazette and a co-founder of Notting Hill Carnival
data.image_attribution: Possibly Seattle Times (archive), Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Clive Sullivan
data.description: Welsh rugby league player, Welsh international player, and first-ever Black captain for Great Britain in any sport

data.name: Connie Mark
data.description: Medical secretary during WWII and co-founder of the Mary Seacole Memorial Association

data.name: Count Suckle
data.description: Sound system operator and club owner who was influential in the development of ska and reggae music, and Caribbean culture in the UK

data.name: Creation of Liberation
data.description: Open exhibition with a large group of Black artists

data.name: Cy Grant
data.description: Actor, musician, writer & poet
data.image_attribution: Angela Cobbinah, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Cyril Blake
data.description: Jazz trumpeter who moved to England from Trinidad and worked as a musician in the 1920s and 1930s

data.name: Cyrille Regis
data.description: International footballer who played 619 league games across his 19-year career
data.image_attribution: Elliott Brown from Birmingham, United Kingdom, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: D L Clemetson
data.description: Born into a wealthy family in Jamaica and was one of the first Black people to serve as a British Army officer during WWI

data.name: DJ Swing
data.description: He was the face of DJ collective Boogie Bunch and won a MOBO award for best club DJ

data.name: Danny Williams
data.description: Singer

data.name: Darcus Howe
data.description: Broadcaster, writer, and racial justice campaigner. One of the Mangrove 9 who was acquitted after charges were brought against him and his friends for inciting violent protests against the police in 1970

data.name: David Pitt
data.description: Politician, general practitioner, and political activist

data.name: Davidson Nicol
data.description: Academic, physician, diplomat, poet, and writer

data.name: Derek B
data.description: UK hip-hop star and was the first UK rapper to appear on BBC's Top of the Pops

data.name: Diane Charlemagne
data.description: Jazz, soul, funk, and electronic singer and songwriter who had 2 UK Top 10 hits and worked with Goldie and Moby

data.name: Dick Turpin
data.description: Middleweight boxer who won one of the first British Boxing titles

data.name: Dido Elizabeth Belle
data.description: Heiress and daughter of British career naval officer, Sir John Lindsay
data.image_attribution: David Martin (previously attributed to Johann Zoffany)

data.name: Dixie Brown
data.description: Professional boxer who couldn't contest any of the British championships because of the colour bar

data.name: Donald Locke
data.description: Guyanese artist who created drawings, paintings, and sculptures in a variety of media

data.name: Donald Rodney
data.description: Artist and leading figure in Britain's BLK Arts Groups in the 1980s and became recognised as one of the most innovative and versatile artists of his generation

data.name: Dorothea A Hendry
data.description: Worked in an aircraft factory during WWII and is one of the first women of colour to allow historians to record her experiences of Exeter during wartime

data.name: Dorothy Kuya
data.description: Human rights activist was involved in establishing Liverpool's International Slavery Museum and served as chair of London housing association Ujima which became the largest Black-led social enterprise in Europe

data.name: Duke Vin
data.description: First sound system operator and selector in Britain. He played a part in popularising ska and was a co-founder of the Notting Hill Carnival

data.name: Earl Cameron
data.description: Actor
data.image_attribution: Peter J Dunn- in my role as Director of Press and Media at the University of Warwick, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Edmund Jenkins
data.description: American composer during the Harlem Renaissance who studied at the Royal Academy of Music in London and composed the award-winning African War Dance

data.name: Edmundo Ros
data.description: Musician, vocalist, arranger, and bandleader
data.image_attribution: Harry Pot / Anefo, CC0, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Edna Thomas
data.description: Actor and a key figure during the Harlem Renaissance. Her open relationship with a female English aristocrat transcended both racial and sexual boundaries of the time

data.name: Edric Connor
data.description: Calypso singer, folklorist and actor

data.name: Elisabeth Welch
data.description: Singer, actress, and entertainer
data.image_attribution: Allan warren, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Errol Brown
data.description: Award-winning singer, songwriter, and lead for funk band Hot Chocolate
data.image_attribution: Ziko van Dijk, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Esther Bruce
data.description: A seamstress whose autobiography became the first to document the life of a Black working-class woman in Britain

data.name: Esther and Rebecca
data.description: Two sisters who posed for 20th-century sculptor, Jacob Epstein

data.name: Eva Lowe
data.description: Jamaican nurse Eva Lowe trained at St Nicholas’ Hospital, London from 1932 and registered in 1935. Despite being well qualified, she was rejected many times before finding employment

data.name: Evelyn Dove
data.description: Singer and actress who was popular during WWII
data.image_attribution: Carl Van Vechten 1880-1964, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Everton Weekes
data.description: Cricketer from Barbados who played in the West Indies team and the Lancashire League

data.name: Exist Loudly
data.description: Organisation for Queer Black youth

data.name: Fanny Coker
data.description: Freed woman who was based in Bristol

data.name: Fanny Eaton
data.description: Artist's model and domestic worker
data.image_attribution: Walter Fryer Stocks, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: FannyAnn Eddy
data.description: LGBT activist and founder of Sierra Leone Lesbian and Gay Association

data.name: Felix Dexter
data.description: Actor, comedian, and writer. After working on the BBC TV show The Real McCoy, Dexter went on to write several pilots and appeared on numerous TV comedy sketch shows

data.name: Felix Hercules
data.description: Journalist, Pan-Africanist, and one of the founders of the Society for Peoples of African Origin and the African Progress Union

data.name: Francis Barber
data.description: Assistant to Dr. Samuel Johnson, writer of the first dictionary
data.image_attribution: Joshua Reynolds, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Frank Critchlow
data.description: Community activist, civil rights campaigner who owned the Mangrove Restaurant in Notting Hill. He was also one of the Mangrove 9, who was charged and then acquitted for inciting violent protests against repeated police raids on his premises.

data.name: Frank Dove
data.description: Boxer and Olympian who represented Great Britain in the Antwerp Summer Olympics of 1920. He was also given a Military Medal for Bravery for his participation in WWI from the British Army

data.name: Frank Rollock
data.description: Steelpan player and bandleader

data.name: Garland Wilson
data.description: Jazz pianist
data.image_attribution: William P. Gottlieb, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Geoff Love
data.description: Prolific arranger and composer of easy listening and pop versions of film themes

data.name: George Africanus
data.description: Won his freedom from enslavement and then became Nottingham's first Black entrepreneur
data.image_attribution: The Dilettante Society on George Africanus

data.name: George Berry
data.description: London's first black pub owner and licensee. The Coach and Horse pub in Brixton was burnt down in a racist fire attack in 1965

data.name: George Bridgetower
data.description: A virtuoso violinist who impressed Beethoven and a member of the British Royal family who oversaw his music education
data.image_attribution: Stephencdickson, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: George Edward Doney
data.description: Enslaved Gambian man who arrived in England as a servant for the Earl of Essex and served the family for 44 years

data.name: George Padmore
data.description: Journalist, activist, and principal organiser of the Manchester Pan-African Conference in 1945 and was an adviser to Kwame Nkrumah

data.name: George Powe
data.description: Labour unionist, activist, and politician who forced Raleigh Industries in Nottingham to create greater equality for black people in the workplace

data.name: George Rose
data.description: Soldier who served in the British Army for 30 years

data.name: George Watteau
data.description: Personal servant to David Livingstone

data.name: Gertrude Paul
data.description: First headteacher in Leeds and was one of the co-founders of the Leeds West Indian Carnival

data.name: Henry Sylvester-Williams
data.description: Lawyer, councillor, and writer who was involved in the Pan African Movement
data.image_attribution: Ernest Herbert Mills, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Harold Jackman
data.description: British born teacher and patron of the arts who was known for his involvement in the Harlem Renaissance and gay community

data.name: Harold Moody
data.description: Physician and racial justice campaigner and established the League of Coloured People in 1931

data.name: Harry Baird
data.description: Actor with more than 36 film appearances throughout his career
data.image_attribution: Galatea S.P.A., Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Harry Edward
data.description: Runner and Olympian
data.image_attribution: Agence Rol, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Harry Quashi
data.description: Actor who also featured In the Black Bloomsbury set, a homoerotic study

data.name: Helene Yelin
data.description: Artist's model for Jacob Epstein and William Patrick Roberts

data.name: Henri Jetto
data.description: Yeoman and first Black person to vote in Britain
data.image_attribution: Henry Jetto (1569/70–1627), Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Henry Thomas
data.description: Companion and muse for artist Glyn Philpot RA

data.name: IA Audain
data.description: Performer

data.name: Iggy Quail
data.description: Jazz and reggae pianist

data.name: Ignatius Sancho
data.description: Abolitionist and writer
data.image_attribution: Gilbert Stuart, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Ipswich Man
data.description: Forensic investigation of a skeleton from an archaeological dig at a friary in Ipswich determined he originated from Africa

data.name: Ira Aldridge
data.description: Actor and playwright
data.image_attribution: James Northcote, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Isabelle Lucas
data.description: Actor who joined the first British sitcom with an all-Black cast in the 1970s, The Fosters

data.name: Ivor Cummings
data.description: Openly gay senior civil servant who devoted much of his life to serving Black citizens who arrived in the UK from Caribbean and African colonies. He was dubbed the gay father of the Windrush generation as he took charge to launch them into British life

data.name: Ivory Bangle Lady
data.description: Skeletal remains of a woman of North African origin were excavated in York in 1901

data.name: James Samuel Risien Russell
data.description: Physician, neurologist, and professor of medicine
data.image_attribution: Anonymous/unknown, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: James Jackson Brown
data.description: Medical doctor

data.name: Jack Leslie
data.description: Football player whose partnership with Sammy Black has gone down in history as one of the very best - in 327 games they scored 319 goals between them

data.name: James Clarke
data.description: James Clarke James was born in British Guiana (now Guyana). When he was 14, he stowed away on a ship bound for Liverpool and was adopted by an Irish family living in the Scotland Road area. James worked on the docks and joined Wavertree Swimming Club. He started teaching children to swim after rescuing many of them from the Leeds and Liverpool Canal. James saved many locals from drowning in the Mersey and the docks, and taught countless others to swim.

data.name: Jack London
data.description: Athlete and Olympian
data.image_attribution: Agence de presse Meurisse, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Jacques Francis
data.description: Salvage diver for the Mary Rose

data.name: James Berry
data.description: Jamaican poet who was at the forefront of championing West Indian and British writing

data.name: James Peters
data.description: The first Black man to play rugby union for England and the only Black player until 1988

data.name: Jane Harry
data.description: Abolitionist, artist, and Quaker

data.name: Janet Olufunmilayo Adegoke
data.description: First Black woman to serve as Mayor of Hammersmith and Fulham

data.name: Jerry Williams
data.description: Trade unionist and community worker, who later became the first Black Mayor of Camden

data.name: Jessica Huntley
data.description: Publisher, and a women's and community activist and founded Bogle-L'Ouverture Publications in 1969
data.image_attribution: Huntley Archives at London Metropolitan Archives

data.name: Jim Williams
data.description: Community activist and Lord Mayor of Bristol

data.name: Jimmie Daniels
data.description: Openly gay cabaret performer, actor, and nightclub owner was involved in the Harlem Renaissance
data.image_attribution: Van Vechten, Carl, 1880-1964, photographer, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Joanna Vassa
data.description: Only surviving child of former enslaved man and anti-slavery campaigner, Olaudah Equiano

data.name: Joanne Campbell
data.description: British actress and drama therapist. One of the founding members of the first British Black female theatre companies, Bibi Crew

data.name: Jocelyn Barrow
data.description: Educator, community activist, and politician, who later became the first Black woman to hold the position of governor of the BBC. She also became the first Black ‘Dame’ for her services to broadcasting

data.name: Joe Casely-Hayford
data.description: Fashion designer

data.name: Joe Clough
data.description: London Transport's first Black motorbus driver

data.name: Joe Green
data.description: Artist who exhibited Black Women in History which featured women who were overlooked during Black History Month in 2019

data.name: Joe Hunte
data.description: Community activist and racial justice campaigner

data.name: Joe Lashley
data.description: First recorded professional Black boxer in Britain

data.name: John Alcindor
data.description: Physician, activist, and a president of the African Progress Union

data.name: John Archer
data.description: First Black Mayor of London and founding president of the African Progress Union
data.image_attribution: Agence Rol, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: John Blanke
data.description: Trumpeter in King Henry VII's court

data.name: John Brown
data.description: Known for his memoir which recounted his enslavement and subsequent escape. He later settled in Britain as a herbalist

data.name: John Charles
data.description: First black player who represented England at the Under-18 matches and first black player for West Ham in 1963

data.name: John Deman
data.description: Sailor who served with Admiral Nelson in the Caribbean

data.name: John Edmonstone
data.description: Taught taxidermy to students at the University of Edinburgh including Charles Darwin

data.name: John Kent
data.description: First recorded Black police officer in Britain

data.name: John La Rose
data.description: Political and cultural activist who founded New Beacon Books - the first specialist Caribbean publishing company in Britain

data.name: John Perkins
data.description: First mixed heritage commissioned officer of the Royal Navy and was regarded as one of the most successful captains of the Georgian Navy

data.name: John Ystumllyn
data.description: Gardener and first well-recorded Black person in North Wale

data.name: Jon Daniel
data.description: Award-winning Creative Director who was responsible for branding Black History Month

data.name: Jonathan Strong
data.description: In a bid for his freedom from enslavement, he was instrumental in a 1772 court case that confimed slavery was not legal in England

data.name: Joseph Emidy
data.description: Violinist and composer

data.name: Joseph Johnson
data.description: A beggar on the streets of London in the early 1800s whose distinctive look included a replica of the ship HMS Nelson on his hat

data.name: Joseph Olubo
data.description: Artist and book illustrator

data.name: Joseph St Clair
data.description: Dentist and businessman

data.name: Josephine Morcashani
data.description: Singer and entertainer who performed across Europe

data.name: Josie Woods
data.description: Pioneering Black dancer and choreographer

data.name: Julius Soubise
data.description: Raised by the Duchess of Queensberry as her own, he lived a life of luxury into adulthood

data.name: Justin Fashunu
data.description: First professional footballer to be openly gay. Inducted into the National Football Museum Hall of Fame

data.name: Katherine Auker
data.description: Took her enslaver to court in 1690 for unfair employment restrictions and won

data.name: Kathleen Wrasama
data.description: Community organiser and founding member of the Stepney Coloured People's Association that helped Black people with housing and education.

data.name: Khadija Saye
data.description: Her work as a photographer explored her Gambian-British identity. The London Transport Museum launched a photography fellowship in her name after her death in the Grenfell fire

data.name: Laureen Sylvestre
data.description: Upholsterer and jewellery maker

data.name: Laurel Aitken
data.description: Singer and one of the pioneers of Jamaican Ska Music

data.name: Laurie Cunningham
data.description: Professional footballer who was the first British man to play for Real Madrid and the first Black player to be called up for the England International team
data.image_attribution: Nationaal Archief, Den Haag, Rijksfotoarchief: Fotocollectie Algemeen Nederlands Fotopersbureau (ANEFO), 1945-1989 - negatiefstroken zwart/wit, nummer toegang 2.24.01.04, bestanddeelnummer 931-7501, CC BY-SA 3.0 NL <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/nl/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Len Garrison
data.description: Educationalist, community activist, and historian. Founded the Black Cultural Archives in 1980 to collect, preserve and celebrate the histories of Caribbean and African people in Britain
data.image_attribution: George Kelly, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Len Woodley
data.description: Barrister and the first person of Afro-Caribbean heritage to become a Queen's Counsel

data.name: Leon Riley
data.description: Musician, compere, and DJ. His big break came when he compered for The Beatles’ first performance in Hull in 1962

data.name: Leslie Hutchinson
data.description: Singer, musician, and cabaret star in the 1920s and 1930s. High profile relationships with women and men include Ivor Novello and Cole Porter

data.name: Lewis Bruce
data.description: Trailblazer

data.name: Lilian Bader
data.description: One of the first black women who joined the British Armed Forces. She became a Leading Aircraft Woman and was then promoted to the rank of Corporal

data.name: Lionel Morrison
data.description: Journalist and the first Black person to hold the office of the President of the National Union of Journalist

data.name: Louis Black
data.description: Artist

data.name: Lulu Coote
data.description: Afro-Dutch nurse who worked in England during WWI

data.name: Mabel Dinah
data.description: 20th century Nurse based in London

data.name: Madeleine Bechet
data.description: Artist’s model for 1921 sculpture, Girl for Senegal by Jacob Epstein

data.name: Marcus Garvey
data.description: Political activist, publisher, journalist, entrepreneur, and orator. He called for unity between Africans and the diaspora and campaigned for an end to European colonial rule across Africa
data.image_attribution: from George Grantham Bain Collection, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Marlene Bogle
data.description: Community Activist, and founder of Brixton Black Women's Center and London's Black Lesbian Centre

data.name: Mary Prince
data.description: Abolitionist, autobiographer and was the first Black woman to present an anti-slavery petition to Parliament

data.name: Mary Seacole
data.description: Nurse and businesswoman

data.name: Massa Kendrick
data.description: 19th century Boxer

data.name: Maud Sulter
data.description: Contemporary fine artist, photographer, writer, educator, and curator. Known for her collaborations with other Black feminist scholars and activists

data.name: Mavis Best
data.description: Spearheaded the Scrap SUS campaign and lobbied the politics for 3 years until the laws were changed

data.name: Michael Akintaro
data.description: Activist who stood up to racists and helped to lay the foundations for the postwar Black community in London

data.name: Mollie Hunte
data.description: Educational Psychologist advocating for fairer treatment of black children in schools

data.name: Momodou Samba
data.description: Signalman in London
data.image_attribution: Blair Blenman, © Transport for London Corporate Archives

data.name: Nana Bonsu
data.description: Born Beresford Evans, he was the chairman for the Manchester branch of the Pan African Congress Movement and regional secretary for the Campaign Against Racial Discrimination, which encouraged the politics to bring in the 1976 Race Relations Act

data.name: Norman Beaton
data.description: Stage and screen actor, best known for his role in Channel 4's sitcom Desmonds

data.name: OBAALA
data.description: Launched the pioneering Black-Art Gallery in North London led by former Black Panther, artist, and poet Shakka Dedi

data.name: Olaudah Equiano
data.description: Writer and abolitionist
data.image_attribution: Daniel Orme, after W. Denton, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Olive Morris
data.description: Radical activist who was heavily involved in the feminist, Black Nationalist, and squatters rights campaigns of the 1970s. She was also a founding member of Brixton Black Women's group

data.name: Oliver Tambo
data.description: President of the African National Congress and lived in London for 30 years in exile
data.image_attribution: Rob C. Croes / Anefo, CC BY-SA 3.0 NL <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/nl/deed.en>, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Omoniyi Bandele
data.description: Nationalist and Pan-Africanist writer best known for his book A Defence for the Ethiopian Movement (1908) which urged for political reforms in the African colonies

data.name: Oscar Abrams
data.description: Theatre designer, community activist, and community organiser

data.name: Oswald Murray
data.description: Painter

data.name: Ottobah Cugoano
data.description: Abolitionist, political activist, and natural rights philosopher
data.image_attribution: Richard Cosway, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Pablo Fanque
data.description: First recorded Black circus owner in Britain and is best known for being mentioned in The Beatle's song Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!

data.name: Patrick Nelson
data.description: Artist model and Prisoner of War during WWII. His biography explores Queer Black London in the 1930s and experiences of the interwar London art world

data.name: Patti Flynn
data.description: Jazz singer and social activist. Founder and patron of Black History Wales

data.name: Paulette Wilson
data.description: Windrush Scandal Campaigner who fought her own deportation to Jamaica

data.name: Pauline Henriques
data.description: Actor and community activist
data.image_attribution: BBC UK Government, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Pearl Alcock
data.description: Artist and owner of a popular gay-friendly cafe in Brixton

data.name: Pearl Prescod
data.description: Singer and actress. One of the earliest Caribbeans to appear on British television and the first black woman to appear at the National Theatre

data.name: Philip Quaque
data.description: The first African to be ordained as a minister by the Church of England

data.name: Princess Ademola
data.description: Nigerian Princess and nurse

data.name: Princess Tshai
data.description: Daughter of Emperor Haile Selassie who trained as a nurse in London and became Ethiopia's first national nurse when she returned to her homeland

data.name: R B A Wellesley-Cole
data.description: First West African to become a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons in England

data.name: Ras Makonnen
data.description: Military leader, governor, and father of Emperor Haile Selassie
data.image_attribution: James Lafayette, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Reginald Foresythe
data.description: Jazz pianist, arranger, composer, and bandleader
data.image_attribution: Daventry B J H (Fg Off), Royal Air Force official photographer, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Richard Baker
data.description: Black Greenwich Pensioner who served aboard HMS Leviathan during the Battle of Trafalgar

data.name: Richie Riley
data.description: Co-founder of Les Ballet Negres, Britain's first Black dance company

data.name: Robert Adams
data.description: Actor, wrestler, barrister, and founding member of the League of Coloured Peoples

data.name: Robert Broadhurst
data.description: Pan-Africanist, journalist, and Vice President of the United African League

data.name: Robert Walker
data.description: Footballer in Scotland during the 1870s

data.name: Robert Wedderburn
data.description: Activist, abolitionist, and preacher whose tract The Horrors of Slavery was used for the anti-slavery cause

data.name: Roddy Kentish
data.description: One of the Mangrove 9 who was arrested following a protest against police raids at the Mangrove club in Notting Hill in 1970

data.name: Ronald Moody
data.description: Sculptor specialising in wood carvings and became a well-known figure in the London art scene during the 1950s and 60s

data.name: Rotimi Fani-Kayode
data.description: Photographer and founding member of Autograph: Association of Black Photographers

data.name: Roy A K Heath
data.description: Schoolteacher and writer

data.name: Roy Francis
data.description: Welsh Rugby Union and League player and professional coach

data.name: Rudi Patterson
data.description: Actor and potter who is best known for his depictions of Caribbean life in his paintings

data.name: Sam King
data.description: Passenger on Empire Windrush who later became a campaigner for West Indians living in the UK. He also became the first Black Mayor of Southwark

data.name: Sam U Morris
data.description: Campaigner

data.name: Sara Baartman
data.description: South African Khoikhoi woman who, due to European objectification of her buttocks, was exhibited as a freak show attraction in London

data.name: Sarah Parker Remond
data.description: Lecturer, activist, and abolitionist

data.name: Scipio Africanus
data.description: Enslaved by the 7th Earl of Suffolk, his grave is inscribed with his poem 'I who am a slave' which has a grade II listing
data.image_attribution: William Avery, CC BY-SA 2.5, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: Shim Sham Club
data.description: Soho-based members club influenced by the Harlem Renaissance and welcomed Black, Queer and Jewish Londoners

data.name: Snakehips Johnson
data.description: Swing bandleader and dancer

data.name: Stuart Hall
data.description: Sociologist, cultural theorist, and political activist who was also responsible for the first-ever cultural studies course in the UK

data.name: Syd Burke
data.description: Broadcaster and photographer. One of the first Black journalists in the UK

data.name: TES Scholes
data.description: Baptist missionary, medical doctor and political commentator. He published a critique of the Colonial Secretary's benefits which were only available to white British subjects

data.name: Tex Ajetunmobi
data.description: Photographer

data.name: The Africa Centre
data.description: Cultural centre initially founded as a friendly meeting place for Africans living in London

data.name: The Yaa Centre
data.description: Afro-Caribbean arts and community centre named after Yaa Asantewaa, politician, Queen, and human rights activist

data.name: Thin Black Line(s)
data.description: Multimedia exhibition featuring 11 Black women artists at the Institute for Contemporary Arts, curated by Lubaina Himid CBE

data.name: Thomas Williams
data.description: Artist

data.name: Tom Molineaux
data.description: Bare-knuckle boxer who found fame with his two fights against the Champion of England at the time
data.image_attribution: Robert Dighton, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons

data.name: UK Black Pride
data.description: Europe's largest Black Gay Pride event celebrating people from the African, Asian, Middle Eastern, Latin American and Caribbean heritage from the LGBTQ+ community

data.name: Ukawsaw Gronniosaw
data.description: His 1772 enslaved narrative autobiography made him the first published African man in Britain

data.name: Una Marson
data.description: Feminist, activist and writer who became the first Black woman to be employed by the BBC during WWII

data.name: Uzo Egonu
data.description: Artist who settled in Britain after the war and whose works combined the visual language of Western and African art

data.name: Val McCalla
data.description: Launched The Voice weekly newspaper in 1982 focussing on Black interests in Britain

data.name: Vincent Reid
data.description: Pioneering educator of African and Caribbean history

data.name: Walter Tull
data.description: Professional footballer and British Army officer

data.name: William Brown
data.description: First known Black woman in the Royal Navy

data.name: William Clarke
data.description: First Black airman to fly for Britain during WWI

data.name: William Cuffay
data.description: Leading figure of the Chartist movement, the first mass popular political movement in Britain

data.name: William Daggers
data.description: Travelled from Jamaica to England to study law and settled in Liverpool as a solicitor

data.name: Winifred Atwell
data.description: Pianist who enjoyed popularity playing boogie-woogie and ragtime hits

data.name: Yemi Agibade
data.description: Playwright, actor, and director

data.name: Zami: A New Spelling of My Name
data.description: Zami: A New Spelling of My Name (1982) by Audre Lorde, tells the story of Audre, the child of African immigrants, growing up in 1940’s Harlem, where she faces extreme prejudice. As she grows up she has several relationships with different women, until finally leaving America for Mexico to escape the Red Scare and McCarthyism. The book deals with issues of race, sexuality and prejudice.
